awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Academic hiring networks and scientific productivity across disciplines
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in science come from the collective and linked efforts of thousands of researchers working within and across disciplines. This project creates rigorous models of the composition, dynamics, and network structure of the United States' scientific workforce across heterogeneous independent institutions with different strengths and emphases.  The systematic influence of these institutional and individual characteristics on scientific advances across disciplines is investigated. The results of this project will generate new insights into the composition of the scientific workforce and scientific productivity across fields. In addition, this project trains new graduate and undergraduate students in cutting-edge computational and statistical research techniques, and will develop and disseminate new large-scale open data sets on the composition of the United States' scientific workforce and provide new software for collecting structured data automatically from open unstructured sources.

This project uses state-of-the-art computational and statistical techniques from network science, machine learning, and social modeling to create a new technology platform for automatically and systematically collecting high-quality structured data on the composition, dynamics, and output of the scientific workforce.  These data will be combined with social survey results of individual researchers and with rigorous network methods to model the relationship between workforce composition, productivity, and observable differences at the individual and institutional levels within and between scientific fields. Mathematical models of the short- and long-term evolution of workforce in order to evaluate the likely outcomes of certain types of interventions and policies are developed.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to create a detailed map of the academic scientific workforce, and to investigate how its composition and dynamics relate to scientific productivity, through three specific aims. (1) Develop smart webcrawling technology that accelerates and automates the collection of faculty career trajectory and productivity data from public sources, for all faculty in any specified field. (2) Survey individual faculty to understand the individual and social context for career events, outcomes, and workforce patterns. (3) Create and validate mathematical models for the assembly and evolution of patterns observed in the workforce over time.
This project developed a new webcrawling platform to collect and annotate detailed educational and professional information from public primary electronic sources. Applied to multiple fields with disparate scholarly practices, it produced comprehensive system-level data on the composition and recent turnover of these academic scientific workforces that enabled novel statistical analyses and a deeper understanding of the causes and effects of academic hiring patterns.
This project reshaped our understanding of four specific aspects of the scientific workforce and their relationship to scholarly outcomes. (1) This project investigated the extent and origin of inequalities in faculty hiring across scholarly disciplines, showing that strong "prestige" hierarchies in hiring are universal across fields and that these hierarchies both emerge and persist under only modest mechanisms of feedback in the context of institutional competition. (2) This project investigated the degree to which prestige hierarchies act as structural factors to shape the spread of ideas across the scientific community, showing that faculty hiring is an important driver of observed epistemic inequalities: more innovative ideas "born" at less prestigious institutions tend to spread less well than less innovative ideas from elite institutions, reinforcing the stratification of which ideas are worked on at different institutions. (3) This project quantified the patterns of early-career scholarly productivity, showing that the canonical pattern, based on 60 years of past work, of a "quick rise to an early peak, followed by a slow decline" is false, as it accurately describes fewer than 30% of studied researchers. Rather, the project showed that productivity trajectories exhibit an enormous diversity, indicating that productivity is much less predictable than expected, and that the main driver of increased productivity is not the prestige or quality of the doctoral program, but rather the prestige of the working environment. This prestige then drives differences in the available scientific labor, i.e., graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. (4) This project investigated the origins and implications of gender inequalities, showing that (4a) parenthood is the main causal source of decreased scientific productivity for female scientists at research intensive institutions, but not for male scientists, which implicates gendered parenting norms, and that (4b) field-level norms around "expectations of brilliance" drive differential migration of male and female scientists from one field to another, which can explain some of the differences in gender composition observed in different domains of science.
These results enable new investigations of the scientific workforce and provide scientifically useful empirical evidence on the origins and implications of social and epistemic inequalities for the science of science and innovation policy.
